   Assessment and Plan
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - f/u CT chest with contrast for ?PE
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction.  While patient was
   initially hemodynamically stable, urine output is diminishing and
   condition is deteriorating
   -EKG to assess for sinal node block
   -check TSH for concern of hypothyroidism
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Also concern for sepsis given
   lactate but otherwise no leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible
   sources of infection include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - follow up Bcxs
   - check LFTs (lipase nl)
   - cont. vanc/zosyn
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.
   - give 2 units FFP, given vitamin K
   -pull femoral line, no central access necessary as patient does not
   wish to escalate care
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - hepatitis panel is pending
   - may be etiology of coagulopathy
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis:
   - cont. calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
   expressed wish  for son to see patient, they do not wish to escalate
   care.  No pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.  Once the central
   line is removed, the family understands that it may not be possible to
   obtain labs to monitor the patient.  They understand that the patient
   clinical status is deteriorating.  Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by
   phone: C - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**]; H - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2149-8-11**] 02:04 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2149-8-11**] 02:26 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2149-8-11**] 02:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: famotidine
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, history of CVA, HTN, and hyponatremia, who was brought to the emergency department for lethargy and was intubated due to acute respiratory distress.

The patient has developed several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been re-intubated due to self-extubation and acidemia, likely caused by hypoventilation. There is no evidence of profound intrapulmonary process, and the lung parenchyma appears normal.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is 43 beats per minute, and her cardiac dysfunction is likely contributing to her condition.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 122/51 mmHg, and her hypotension is likely multifactorial, including poor PO intake, bradycardia, and possible sepsis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged PTT, INR, and low platelets, suggesting disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Liver dysfunction may also be contributing to the coagulopathy.
5. Acidemia: The patient has a respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis, likely due to her respiratory failure and poor tissue perfusion.
6. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's baseline creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, and her ARF is likely due to hypovolemia and ATN from cardiac arrest.
7. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be due to shock liver from cardiac arrest.
8. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's hemoglobin is 10.2 g/dL, and her platelet count is 91 K/uL, suggesting anemia and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued antibiotics to cover HAP
2. Fibrinogen replacement to treat coagulopathy
3. IVF boluses to treat hypotension
4. Renal dose medications to avoid nephrotoxins
5. Limitation of sedatives to avoid compromising patient comfort
6. Removal of femoral line and central access to avoid further complications
7. Discussion of goals of care with family, including DNR status
8. Monitoring of patient's clinical status and adjustment of treatment plan as necessary.

The patient's condition is deteriorating, and her family has expressed a wish to not escalate care. The patient's grandson can be reached by phone for any updates or questions.

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, hypertension, and a history of CVA, who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress and was intubated. She has a history of COPD, hyperinflated on CXR, and a recent left-sided pleural effusion that has improved. She has been diagnosed with a myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and a possible pulmonary embolism.

The patient's recent events include an unplanned extubation, which was re-intubated for acidemia. She has a slow leak from her femoral line, which needs to be addressed. Her blood cultures show 1/4 GPC in pairs and clusters.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.8°C, heart rate of 43 bpm, and blood pressure of 122/51 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's lab results show an elevated troponin, lactic acidosis, and a possible coagulopathy with an elevated PTT, INR, and low platelets. Her electrolytes are also abnormal, with a low potassium level.

The patient's plan includes continuing vanc/zosyn to cover HAP, considering an ECHO to assess for RV strain, and holding empiric anticoagulation at this time. She will also receive ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers and hold on steroids for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further acidemia and hypoxemia.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial infarction can lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Infection: The patient's possible HAP and UTI can lead to further infection and sepsis.
5. Hypovolemia: The patient's hypovolemia can worsen, leading to further hypotension and organ dysfunction.
6. Acidemia: The patient's acidemia can worsen, leading to further respiratory and cardiac complications.
7. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury can worsen, leading to further renal failure and electrolyte disturbances.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's transaminitis can worsen, leading to further liver failure and coagulopathy.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve her outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 19-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of chest pain. The patient's 24-hour events include an unplanned extubation, which was re-intubated due to acidemia. The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T and creatine kinase (CK) levels, consistent with a myocardial infarction (MI). The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a blood pressure of 122/51 mmHg and a heart rate of 43 beats per minute.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's unplanned extubation and re-intubation may have increased the risk of pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's myocardial infarction may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate levels may indicate the presence of sepsis.
5. Multi-organ dysfunction: The patient's underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of multi-organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and respiratory failure.
6. DVT: The patient's immobility and the use of central venous catheters may increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
7. VAP: The patient's use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central venous catheter may increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of stress ulcer.
9. Myocardial rupture: The patient's myocardial infarction may increase the risk of myocardial rupture.
10. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's myocardial infarction may increase the risk of cardiac tamponade.

Based on the patient's underlying condition and the potential medical complications that can arise, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and hemodynamic status. The patient's family should be educated on the patient's condition and the potential complications that can arise, and the patient's code status should be respected.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory distress:  Current satting 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural
   effusion persists though likely not large enough to cause agonal
   breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear too bad--no
   ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion of overt pulm edema on
   CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though prior ECGs show
   bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of COPD, hyperinflated
   on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - f/u CT chest with contrast for ?PE
   - consider ECHO to assess for RV strain
   - hold empiric anticoagulation at this time
   - ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers
   - hold on steroids for now
   .
   # Hypotension:  This is likely hypovolemic in setting of poor po
   intake.  Also concern for sepsis given lactate but otherwise no
   leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible sources of infection
   include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be cardiac.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - follow up Bcxs
   - check LFTs (lipase nl)
   - cont. vanc/zosyn
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - serial CEs
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  DIC is a concern with elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  No active
   bleeding.  INR increasing, likely nutritional, however also with
   elevated LFTs.
   - check hemolysis labs, peripheral smear for schistocytes
   - trend coags, CBC
   - vitamin K
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # Elevated troponin:  Likely from cardiac arrest.  Did not appear to
   have received electric shocks.
   - serial CEs, EKG
   - ASA
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - check urine lytes, sed, eos.
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - follow LFTs
   - check hep A, B, C serologies
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - check hemolysis labs, retic count
   - guaiac stools
   - monitor CBC [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - cont. simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis:
   - cont. calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Ppx:  pneumoboots, famotidine
   # FEN:  IVF boluses, monitor/replete electrolytes
   # Access:  L femoral line, will need to be resited if okay with goals
   of care
   # Code:  DNR, confirmed with grandson
   # Communication: With family. Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by
   phone: C - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**]; H - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, history of CVA, HTN, hyponatremia, and COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory distress and intubated. The patient has undergone several interventions, including cardiac arrest, and has been treated with various medications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. The patient's SpO2 is 100%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of myocardial infarction, and the electrocardiogram (ECG) shows evidence of L-sided effusion. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus bradycardia, and the blood pressure is 122/51 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not reported, but the patient is receiving IV fluids and has a fluid balance of 1,594 mL.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and the blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26 mg/dL.
* Liver: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 602 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 684 IU/L.
* Coagulation: The patient has a coagulopathy with elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and international normalized ratio (INR), and low platelet count.
* Electrolytes: The patient's potassium level is 4.9 mEq/L, and the magnesium level is 1.7 mg/dL.
* Blood glucose: The patient's blood glucose level is 121 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and the risk of respiratory failure is high.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and the risk of recurrent cardiac arrest is high.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of sepsis due to the presence of a central venous catheter and the patient's immunocompromised state.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the risk of acute kidney injury is high.
5. Liver failure: The patient's LFTs are elevated, and the risk of liver failure is high.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, and the risk of bleeding is high.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and the risk of electrolyte imbalance is high.
8. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the risk of hypotension is high.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following interventions may be necessary:

1. Continuous monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results.
2. Adjustment of the patient's mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Administration of antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
4. Management of the patient's coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma and platelet transfusions.
5. Monitoring of the patient's electrolyte levels and administration of electrolyte supplements as necessary.
6. Monitoring of the patient's blood glucose level and administration of insulin as necessary.
7. Monitoring of the patient's creatinine level and administration of dialysis as necessary.
8. Monitoring of the patient's LFTs and administration of medications to prevent liver failure.
9. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac status and administration of medications to prevent cardiac arrest.
10. Communication with the patient's family and healthcare team to ensure that the patient's goals of care are respected.

The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and intubation. They have a history of self-extubation and required reintubation due to ventilatory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 44 bpm, blood pressure of 122/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is sedated and exhibits bradycardia, which is not accompanied by hemodynamic compromise.

The patient's physical examination reveals a general appearance of being frail and not well-nourished. They have a normal-sized head, ears, nose, and throat, with no signs of poor dentition or nasal congestion. The patient's cardiovascular examination shows a normal pulse, blood pressure, and no signs of cardiac murmur or rub. The respiratory examination reveals symmetric chest expansion, resonant percussion, and clear breath sounds.

The patient's laboratory results indicate mild lactic acid elevation, likely due to hypoperfusion, and mild liver enzyme elevation, possibly related to shock liver or hypotension. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for hypocalcemia, which has been repleted. The patient's coagulation profile shows elevated D-dimer levels, indicating potential coagulopathy.

The patient's medical history is significant for respiratory failure, and their code status is DNR (do not resuscitate). The patient's disposition is ICU, and they require ongoing critical care management.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest or dysrhythmia, potentially related to the patient's underlying condition or medications.
2. Sepsis or septic shock, potentially related to the patient's respiratory failure or other underlying conditions.
3. Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis, potentially related to the patient's immobility and underlying conditions.
4. Hypovolemic shock, potentially related to the patient's fluid losses and underlying conditions.
5. Neurological complications, potentially related to the patient's underlying condition or medications, such as cerebral edema, seizures, or stroke.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend continued close monitoring and management of their respiratory and cardiovascular status, as well as ongoing assessment for potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure. The patient self-extubated yesterday and required reintubation for ventilatory failure. They remain intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 44 beats per minute, blood pressure of 122/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's physical examination reveals a generally well-nourished appearance, with no acute distress. The eyes are normal, and the cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. The patient has a soft and non-tender abdomen, with bowel sounds present. The skin is warm and has no rash or jaundice.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and liver enzymes. The patient has mild hypocalcemia, which has been repleted. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus bradycardia.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to unclear precipitant. The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation, adjust settings towards spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) and extubation.
2. Pulseless arrest: The patient had a pulseless arrest, which is unclear whether related to the precipitant for admission or possibly related to the induction and intubation event. The plan is to monitor for cardiac event, consider cardiac echo, and neurological evaluation including head CT and EEG.
3. Bradycardia: The patient has unclear etiology for bradycardia, with concerns including hypothyroidism or intrinsic cardiac conduction disease. The plan is to check cardiac echo and TSH.
4. Dilated right atrium: The patient may have right-side valvular heart disease or pulmonary hypertension. The plan is to check echo.
5. Hypotension: The patient has unclear etiology for hypotension, with concerns including hypovolemia, underlying process prompting admission, or related to induction/intubation. The plan is to monitor blood pressure and maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient has mild hypocalcemia, which has been repleted. The plan is to monitor ionized calcium.
7. Lactic acid elevation: The patient has mild lactic acid elevation, likely due to hypoperfusion. The plan is to monitor abdominal examination for possible ischemia.
8. Liver function test (LFT) elevation: The patient has mild LFT elevation, which is resolving. The plan is to trend serial LFTs, check amylase and lipase, and consider RUQ ultrasound.
9. Fluids: The patient has hypovolemia, which has improved with aggressive IV repletion in the emergency department. The plan is to monitor I/O.
10. IV access: The patient has IV access via a left femoral line, which will be discontinued and replaced with a peripheral IV.

The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and their disposition is to remain in the ICU.

 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   -limit sedation as much as possible
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism.  The
   patient remains hemodynamically stable with adequate urine output
   -continue levothyroxine 25 mg IV
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Concern for sepsis given lactate
   and bacteremia (GPC in clusters and pairs) but otherwise no
   leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible sources of infection
   include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - GPC in clusters and chains: continue vancomycin
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.  No active
   bleeding after 2 units FFP and s/p removal of femoral line
   - continue vitamin K
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - hepatitis panel is pending
   - may be etiology of coagulopathy
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis: d/c calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
   expressed wish  for son to see patient, they do not wish to escalate
   care.  No pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.  Once the central
   line is removed, the family understands that it may not be possible to
   obtain labs to monitor the patient.  They understand that the patient
   clinical status is deteriorating.  Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by
   phone: C - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**]; H - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Add D5W to any fluid boluses

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, history of CVA, HTN, and hyponatremia (thought to be SIADH). She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress and was intubated. The patient has been diagnosed with myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and bradycardia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 43 beats per minute (bradycardic)
* Blood pressure: 138/49 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Oxygen delivery device: Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow

The patient has been receiving various medications, including midazolam, fentanyl, famotidine, and vancomycin. She has also received two units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and has had her femoral line removed.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.2-5.6 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.5-7.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 91-94 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1-0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.13-0.11 ng/mL
* TCO2: 26-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 121-67 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 15.9/35.4/1.4, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 259/9/0.11, ALT/AST: 684/602, Alk Phos/T Bili: 29/0.6, Differential-Neuts: 85.0%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 10.0%, Mono: 5.0%, Eos: 0.0%, D-dimer: 2574 ng/mL, Fibrinogen: 122 mg/dL, Lactic Acid: 2.0 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.9 g/dL, LDH: 335 IU/L, Ca++: 7.5 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.7 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis and plan include:

* Myocardial infarction, acute (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Bradycardia
* Hypotension
* Coagulopathy
* Acidemia
* Acute kidney injury (ARF)
* Transaminitis
* Anemia/thrombocytopenia
* Hypertension
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Osteoporosis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias due to bradycardia
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacteremia or other sources of infection
* Coagulopathy leading to bleeding or thrombosis
* Acidemia leading to respiratory failure or cardiac arrest
* Acute kidney injury leading to electrolyte imbalances or other complications
* Transaminitis leading to coagulopathy or other complications
* Anemia/thrombocytopenia leading to bleeding or other complications
* Hypertension leading to cardiovascular complications
* Hypercholesterolemia leading to cardiovascular complications
* Osteoporosis leading to fractures or other complications

The patient's family has chosen not to escalate care, and the patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - f/u CT chest with contrast for ?PE
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction.  While patient was
   initially hemodynamically stable, urine output is diminishing and
   condition is deteriorating
   -EKG to assess for sinal node block
   -check TSH for concern of hypothyroidism
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Also concern for sepsis given
   lactate but otherwise no leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible
   sources of infection include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - follow up Bcxs
   - check LFTs (lipase nl)
   - cont. vanc/zosyn
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.
   - give 2 units FFP, given vitamin K
   -pull femoral line, no central access necessary as patient does not
   wish to escalate care
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - hepatitis panel is pending
   - may be etiology of coagulopathy
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis:
   - cont. calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
   expressed wish  for son to see patient, they do not wish to escalate
   care.  No pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.  Once the central
   line is removed, the family understands that it may not be possible to
   obtain labs to monitor the patient.  They understand that the patient
   clinical status is deteriorating.  Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, history of CVA, HTN, hyponatremia, and a recent admission to the ICU for acute respiratory distress and myocardial infarction.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving oxygen therapy with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. The lung parenchyma appears normal, and there is no evidence of pulmonary edema or ARDS.
* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is 43 beats per minute, which is considered bradycardic. The cause is likely cardiac dysfunction, and the patient's condition is deteriorating.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 138/49 mmHg, which is considered hypotensive. The cause is likely multifactorial, including poor PO intake, bradycardia, and possible sepsis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated PTT, INR, and low platelets, which suggests a coagulopathy. The etiology is likely disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or liver dysfunction.
* Acidemia: The patient has a respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's baseline creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, which is likely due to hypovolemia or ATN from cardiac arrest.
* Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be due to shock liver or liver dysfunction.
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's baseline HCT is 40, and she has thrombocytopenia.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is controlled, and antihypertensives are not being administered.
* Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's cholesterol levels are not controlled, and simvastatin is not being administered.
* Osteoporosis: The patient's calcium and vitamin D levels are not controlled.

The patient's family has decided not to escalate care, and the patient is not receiving pressors, central access, or CPR. The patient's condition is deteriorating, and the family is aware of the risks involved.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Progressive respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Sepsis
* Coagulopathy
* ARF
* Transaminitis
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia
* Hypertension
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Osteoporosis

The patient's management plan includes:

* Continuing vanc/zosyn for HAP
* F/u CT chest with contrast for possible PE
* Continuing ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
* Limiting sedatives without compromising patient comfort
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis
* Checking U/A and UCx for possible sources of infection
* Following up on blood cultures
* Continuing vanc/zosyn
* Giving 2 units of FFP and vitamin K for coagulopathy
* Removing femoral line and obtaining adequate hemostasis
* Monitoring for signs of ARF
* Renally dosing medications and avoiding nephrotoxins
* Considering a change in antibiotics if the patient's condition deteriorates
* Discussing goals of care with the family and updating them on the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, hypertension, and a history of CVA, hyponatremia, and chronic respiratory failure. She was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure, acute myocardial infarction, and cardiac dysfunction.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with FiO2 50% and PEEP 5 cmH2O. She has a history of chronic respiratory failure and hyperinflation on CXR.
* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is 43 bpm, which is considered bradycardic. The patient has a history of cardiac dysfunction, and the ECG shows bilateral atrial enlargement.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 138/49 mmHg, which is considered hypotensive. The patient has a history of poor PO intake, bradycardia, and possible sepsis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has elevated PTT, INR, and low platelets, which suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient also has liver dysfunction, which may be contributing to the coagulopathy.
* Acidemia: The patient has a respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's baseline creatinine is 0.8, which is considered normal. However, the patient's urine output is diminishing, and the creatinine is increasing.
* Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be due to shock liver from cardiac arrest.
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient has a baseline HCT of 40, which is considered anemia. The patient also has thrombocytopenia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
* Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac dysfunction can worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or cardiac failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and possible sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding or thrombosis.
* Acidemia: The patient's acidemia can worsen, leading to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's ARF can worsen, leading to kidney failure and end-stage renal disease.
* Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis can worsen, leading to liver failure.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the family does not wish to escalate care. The patient's grandson can be reached by phone at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**] or [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44.9 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI), acute respiratory failure, and a code status of DNR (do not resuscitate).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate of 43 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 138/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus bradycardia.

The patient is receiving various medications, including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, midazolam, and fentanyl, for treatment of suspected sepsis. They are also receiving famotidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating ongoing myocardial damage. Their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, suggesting kidney dysfunction. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 12 inspirations per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100% on 50% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). They are receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a peak inspiratory pressure of 28 cmH2O.

The patient's physical examination is unremarkable, with no signs of congestive heart failure, respiratory distress, or other significant abnormalities.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of acute myocardial infarction and ongoing myocardial damage, they are at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to the need for increased ventilator support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
3. Sepsis: The patient's suspected sepsis may progress, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and a higher risk of mortality.
4. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels may indicate worsening kidney function, which could lead to the need for dialysis.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's abnormal LFTs may indicate ongoing liver damage, which could lead to coagulopathy, jaundice, or other complications.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of acute myocardial infarction and ongoing cardiovascular instability may increase their risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be sufficient to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to complications such as bleeding, shock, or even death.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - f/u CT chest with contrast for ?PE
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction.  While patient was
   initially hemodynamically stable, urine output is diminishing and
   condition is deteriorating
   -EKG to assess for sinal node block
   -check TSH for concern of hypothyroidism
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Also concern for sepsis given
   lactate but otherwise no leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible
   sources of infection include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - follow up Bcxs
   - check LFTs (lipase nl)
   - cont. vanc/zosyn
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.
   - give 2 units FFP, given vitamin K
   -pull femoral line, no central access necessary as patient does not
   wish to escalate care
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - hepatitis panel is pending
   - may be etiology of coagulopathy
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis:
   - cont. calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
   expressed wish  for son to see patient, they do not wish to escalate
   care.  No pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.  Once the central
   line is removed, the family understands that it may not be possible to
   obtain labs to monitor the patient.  They understand that the patient
   clinical status is deteriorating.  Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by
   phone: C - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**]; H - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with a history of CVA, HTN, hyponatremia, and dementia who was brought to the ED in acute respiratory distress and intubated. She has been diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (AMI), acute respiratory failure, and possible sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is 43 beats per minute, which is likely due to cardiac dysfunction.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 138/49 mmHg, which is likely multifactorial and may be due to poor PO intake, bradycardia, and possible sepsis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has elevated PTT, INR, and low platelets, which may be due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or liver dysfunction.
* Acidemia: The patient has a respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis, which may be due to chronic respiratory disease and poor tissue perfusion.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's baseline Cr is 0.8, which may be due to hypovolemia or ATN from cardiac arrest.
* Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be due to shock liver from cardiac arrest or liver dysfunction.
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient has a baseline HCT of 40 and thrombocytopenia, which may be due to chronic disease or bleeding.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is controlled, but hypertension is not a current concern.
* Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's lipid profile is not currently a concern.
* Osteoporosis: The patient is receiving calcium and vitamin D supplements.
* Communication: The patient's family has been informed of her deteriorating condition and has chosen not to escalate care.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's lactate level is elevated, and she may be at risk for sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further, requiring increased ventilatory support.
* Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function may continue to deteriorate, leading to cardiac arrest.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
* Acidemia: The patient's acidemia may worsen, leading to further respiratory and cardiac compromise.
* ARF: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to further kidney damage and electrolyte imbalance.
* Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction and coagulopathy.

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status
* IVF boluses as needed for hypotension
* Check U/A and UCx for possible sources of infection
* Follow-up Bcxs for sepsis
* Check LFTs for liver dysfunction
* Cont. vanc/zosyn for HAP
* Give 2 units FFP for coagulopathy
* Pull femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
* IVFs for lactic acidosis
* Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins for ARF
* Hepatitis panel pending for transaminitis
* Remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
* Continue calcium and vitamin D supplements for osteoporosis
* Discuss goals of care with family and respect their wishes not to escalate care.

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old woman with a history of CVA, HTN, and hyponatremia, who was brought to the ED in acute respiratory distress and was intubated. She has been diagnosed with myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and sepsis. She is currently hemodynamically stable but has developed bradycardia, hypotension, and coagulopathy. Her laboratory results show elevated lactate levels, bacteremia, and abnormal liver function tests. She has a respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis, and her baseline creatinine level is 0.8. She is also experiencing transaminitis and anemia/thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and elevated lactate levels suggest that she may be developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
3. Cardiac Dysfunction: The patient's bradycardia and hypotension may be related to cardiac dysfunction, which can lead to decreased cardiac output and organ perfusion.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen if not managed properly, leading to bleeding complications.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's baseline creatinine level of 0.8 and her recent IV contrast exposure may increase her risk of developing acute kidney injury.
6. Liver Dysfunction: The patient's transaminitis and abnormal liver function tests may indicate liver dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy, bleeding complications, and increased risk of infection.
7. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's poor oral intake and lack of nutrition may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which can exacerbate her underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for signs of sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac dysfunction.
2. Manage the patient's respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding risk, and consider transfusions or other interventions as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider liver-directed therapy if necessary.
5. Provide adequate nutrition and hydration to the patient, and consider enteral or parenteral nutrition if necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a cardiologist or intensivist to further manage the patient's cardiac dysfunction and respiratory failure.
7. Continue to communicate with the patient's family and granddaughter about the patient's condition and treatment plan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory failure is unclear in terms of precipitant, and no evidence of pneumonia, infection, sepsis, or pulmonary embolism is present. The patient's cardiac status is also unstable, with a pulseless arrest event that has been stabilized without further hemodynamic complications. The patient's bradycardia is unclear in terms of etiology, and concerns include hypothyroidism or intrinsic cardiac conduction disease.

The patient has several laboratory results that are abnormal, including:

* Elevated troponin-T levels, suggesting possible cardiac injury
* Elevated lactate levels, indicating possible hypoperfusion
* Elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which are resolving but unclear in terms of etiology
* Hypocalcemia, which has been repleted
* Bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin
* Dilation of the right atrium, which may represent right-side valvular heart disease or pulmonary hypertension

The patient's fluid status is also concerning, with hypovolemia that has improved with aggressive IV repletion in the emergency department. The patient's nutrition and glycemic control are being monitored, and prophylactic measures are in place for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and their disposition is to remain in the ICU. The patient's total time spent in the ICU is 35 minutes.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Cardiac arrest or arrhythmias
* Hypothyroidism or other endocrine disorders
* Liver or kidney injury
* DVT or pulmonary embolism
* VAP or other ventilator-associated complications
* Hypocalcemia or other electrolyte imbalances
* Fluid overload or dehydration

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and the precipitant of the respiratory failure is unclear.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and CKMB, indicating possible cardiac damage. The patient's ECG shows sinus bradycardia, which may be related to hypothyroidism or intrinsic cardiac conduction disease. The patient's TSH level is greater than 25, indicating hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to the bradycardia.

The patient's physical examination shows signs of hypotension, and the patient's blood pressure is being monitored. The patient's lactate level is elevated, indicating possible hypoperfusion, and the patient's LFTs are mildly elevated, possibly due to shock liver from hypotension.

The patient's medical history includes a history of thyroid disease, and the patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease.

The patient's plan includes continuing mechanical ventilation, adjusting the ventilator settings towards spontaneous breathing trials, and assessing for cardiac events. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient is being monitored closely in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin-T and CK levels indicate possible cardiac damage, which may lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level greater than 25 indicates hypothyroidism, which may lead to further complications such as bradycardia, hypotension, and cardiac arrest if left untreated.
4. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and elevated lactate level indicate possible sepsis, which may lead to further complications such as organ failure, shock, and death.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance shows a significant amount of fluid being administered, which may lead to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary edema and cardiac failure.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   -limit sedation as much as possible
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism.  The
   patient remains hemodynamically stable with adequate urine output
   -continue levothyroxine 25 mg IV
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Concern for sepsis given lactate
   and bacteremia (GPC in clusters and pairs) but otherwise no
   leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible sources of infection
   include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn

   - continue vitamin K

   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2

   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on

   - hepatitis panel is pending

   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S

   .

   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old woman with a history of CVA, HTN, and hyponatremia, who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress and intubated. She has a history of COPD, hyperinflated on CXR, and has been treated with ipratropium and albuterol nebulizers. She has also been diagnosed with a myocardial infarction and has a code status of DNR (do not resuscitate).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to hypoventilation caused by deconditioning or sedation. She has a history of COPD and hyperinflated on CXR, which may contribute to her respiratory failure.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia is likely caused by cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with levothyroxine.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial, caused by poor PO intake, bradycardia, and possible sepsis. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with IVF boluses.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely caused by DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) and liver dysfunction. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with vitamin K.
5. Acidemia: The patient's acidemia is likely caused by respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with IVFs.
6. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): The patient's ARF is likely caused by hypovolemia and ATN (acute tubular necrosis) from cardiac arrest. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with IVFs.
7. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is likely caused by shock liver from cardiac arrest. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with hepatitis panel.
8. Anemia and Thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia are likely caused by chronic kidney disease and cardiac arrest. She has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with T&S (transfusion and splenectomy).

Based on the patient's progress note, it appears that she has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, bradycardia, hypotension, coagulopathy, acidemia, ARF, transaminitis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. She has a code status of DNR and has been treated with various medications and interventions to manage her condition.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old Cantonese-speaking woman with dementia, hypertension, and a history of CVA, hyponatremia, and COPD, who was brought to the emergency department in acute respiratory distress and was intubated. She has a diagnosis of myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and bradycardia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.3°C (95.5°F)
* Heart rate: 45 bpm
* Blood pressure: 130/53 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Oxygen delivery device: Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* FiO2: 50%
* PEEP: 5 cmH2O

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 7.2-5.6 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 35.0-30.0%
* Platelet count: 91-94 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1-0.8 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.13-0.11 ng/mL
* TCO2: 26-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 121-67 mg/dL
* Other labs: elevated PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Differential-Neuts, D-dimer, Fibrinogen, Lactic Acid, Albumin, LDH, Ca++, Mg++, PO4

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: unresponsive sedated
* HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear
* Neck: supple, edematous
* Lungs: course breath sounds
* CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
* GU: foley in place
* Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, 2+ bilateral LE edema

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: stable on volume assist FiO2 50%, PEEP 5, considering PE given marked [**Last Name (un)**]
* Bradycardia: likely cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism, continuing levothyroxine 25 mg IV, and limiting sedatives without compromising patient comfort
* Hypotension: likely multifactorial in setting of poor PO intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis, considering IVF boluses prn and checking U/A, UCx
* Coagulopathy: likely DIC, continuing vancomycin, and considering FFP and platelet transfusions
* Acidemia: likely respiratory acidosis and lactic acidosis, allowing higher PCO2 and IVFs for lactic acidosis
* ARF: likely hypovolemia and ATN from cardiac arrest, considering IVFs and renally dosed meds
* Transaminitis: likely from shock liver from cardiac arrest, trending down
* Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: baseline HCT is 40, considering T&S and holding on following crits for now
* Hypertension: antihypertensives held as pressures are stable
* Hypercholesterolemia: simvastatin discontinued for elevated LFTs
* Osteoporosis: calcium and vitamin D discontinued
* Communication: discussed goals of care with family, including DNR and no pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: worsening hypoxia, respiratory acidosis, and potential need for mechanical ventilation
* Bradycardia: worsening cardiac dysfunction, hypothyroidism, and potential need for pacemaker or cardioverter-defibrillator
* Hypotension: worsening hypovolemia, sepsis, and potential need for vasopressors and inotropes
* Coagulopathy: worsening bleeding, potential need for FFP and platelet transfusions, and potential risk of cerebral or gastrointestinal bleeding
* Acidemia: worsening respiratory acidosis, lactic acidosis, and potential need for mechanical ventilation and vasopressors
* ARF: worsening kidney injury, potential need for dialysis, and potential risk of cardiovascular and neurological complications
* Transaminitis: worsening liver dysfunction, potential need for liver transplantation, and potential risk of coagulopathy and bleeding
* Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: worsening anemia and thrombocytopenia, potential need for blood transfusions, and potential risk of bleeding and infection
* Hypertension: worsening hypertension, potential need for antihypertensives, and potential risk of cardiovascular and renal complications
* Hypercholesterolemia: worsening hypercholesterolemia, potential need for statins, and potential risk of cardiovascular and neurological complications
* Osteoporosis: worsening osteoporosis, potential need for bisphosphonates, and potential risk of fractures and osteopenia.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current stable on volume assist FiO2 50%, PEEP
   5.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by deconditioning or sedation;
   there does not appear to be profound intrapulmonary process.  No new
   xray, but hx of bilateral effusions.  The lung parenchyma itself does
   not appear markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no
   suggestion of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked
   [**Last Name (un) **] (though prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a
   history of COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - family mtg today to discuss goals of care
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   - limit sedation as much as possible
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism.  The
   patient remains hemodynamically stable with adequate urine output
   -continue levothyroxine 25 mg IV
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Concern for sepsis given lactate
   and bacteremia (GPC in clusters and pairs) but otherwise no
   leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible sources of infection
   include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - GPC in clusters and chains: continue vancomycin
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.  No active
   bleeding after 2 units FFP and s/p removal of femoral line
   - continue vitamin K
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs
   - renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Transaminitis:  [**Month (only) 11**] be from shock liver from cardiac arrest.
   - hepatitis panel is pending
   - may be etiology of coagulopathy
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis: d/c calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
   expressed wish  for son to see patient, they do not wish to escalate
   care.  No pressors, transcutaneous pacing, CPR, etc.  Once the central
   line is removed, the family understands that it may not be possible to
   obtain labs to monitor the patient.  They understand that the patient
   clinical status is deteriorating.  Grandson [**Doctor Last Name 6971**] can be reached by
   phone: C - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6980**]; H - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6981**].
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old woman with a history of CVA, HTN, hyponatremia, and dementia who was brought to the ED for lethargy and was intubated due to acute respiratory distress. She has a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and respiratory failure. She is currently stable on volume assist with FiO2 50% and PEEP 5, but has a history of bilateral effusions and hyperinflated lungs on CXR. She also has a history of COPD.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 45 bpm and a blood pressure of 130/53 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100%. Her physical examination reveals a supple neck, regular rate and rhythm, and normal S1 and S2 heart sounds.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.2 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 35.0 g/L, and a platelet count of 91 x 10^9/L. Her liver function tests are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 684 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 602 IU/L. Her renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's medical conditions include myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and coagulopathy. She is also at risk for sepsis, acidemia, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's lactate level is elevated, and she has bacteremia, which may indicate sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100%. She has a history of bilateral effusions and hyperinflated lungs on CXR, which may indicate respiratory failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's platelet count is 91 x 10^9/L, and her prothrombin time (PT) and international normalized ratio (INR) are elevated, which may indicate coagulopathy.
4. Acidemia: The patient's pH is 7.24, which may indicate acidemia.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
6. Myocardial infarction: The patient has a diagnosis of AMI, which may indicate ongoing cardiac damage.
7. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is 50 mmHg, which may indicate respiratory acidosis.

Based on the patient's medical conditions and potential complications, it is recommended that she be closely monitored and managed to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 44.9 kg male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and acute respiratory failure. He has been receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and is being ventilated with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.3°C, heart rate of 45 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/53 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating ongoing myocardial damage. His white blood cell count is 7.2 K/uL, and his platelet count is 91. His hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL, and his creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to his respiratory failure, and his neurological examination is not assessable.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and prolonged mechanical ventilation make him at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged ventilation and potential for aspiration increase his risk for developing VAP.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's myocardial infarction and ongoing cardiac damage make him at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing infection and potential for secondary infections increase his risk for developing sepsis.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure and potential for worsening respiratory function make him at risk for developing respiratory failure.
6. Worsening cardiac function: The patient's ongoing myocardial damage and potential for further cardiac damage make him at risk for developing worsening cardiac function.
7. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential for further renal damage make him at risk for developing renal failure.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   87 yo Cantonese Speaking woman with dementia, h/o CVA, HTN,
   hyponatremia (thought [**3-17**] SIADH), who was brought to the ED by her
   family for lethargy, found to be in acute respiratory distress, and was
   intubated.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Current sating 100% on FiO2 40%, PEEP 5.
   Re-intubated yesterday after self extubation [**3-17**] acidemia likely due to
   hypoventilation.  Hypoventilation may have been caused by
   deconditioning or sedation.  There does not appear to be profound
   intrapulmonary process.  L-sided effusion appears greatly improved from
   [**2149-8-2**].  R pleural effusion persists though likely not large enough to
   cause agonal breathing.  The lung parenchyma itself does not appear
   markedly abnormal --no ground glass opacity on CT chest, no suggestion
   of overt pulm edema on CXR.  [**Month (only) 11**] consider PE given marked [**Last Name (un) **] (though
   prior ECGs show bilateral AE, no ECHO in system).  Has a history of
   COPD, hyperinflated on CXR.
   - grandson asked to hold off on diagnostic [**Female First Name (un) 231**]
   - cont. vanc/zosyn to cover HAP
   - cont. ipratropium/albuterol nebulizers for COPD
   -limit sedation as much as possible
   #Bradycardia: likely [**3-17**] cardiac dysfunction and hypothyroidism.  The
   patient remains hemodynamically stable with adequate urine output
   -continue levothyroxine 25 mg IV
   -limit  sedatives without compromising patient comfort
   -family does not wish to escalate care: no pressors, transcutaneous
   pacing, atropine, etc.
   # Hypotension:  This is likely multifactorial in setting of poor po
   intake, bradycardia, possible sepsis.  Concern for sepsis given lactate
   and bacteremia (GPC in clusters and pairs) but otherwise no
   leukocytosis, tachycardia, fever.  Possible sources of infection
   include empyema, pneumonia, UTI.
   - IVF boluses prn
   - check U/A, UCx
   - GPC in clusters and chains: continue vancomycin
   .
   # Coagulopathy:  Etiology likely [**3-17**] DIC- elevated PTT, INR, low
   platelets, low HCT (baseline is 40), and low fibrinogen.  Liver
   dysfunction may also be possible etiology of coagulopathy.  No active
   bleeding after 2 units FFP and s/p removal of femoral line
   - continue vitamin K
   .
   # Acidemia:  Pt has a respiratory acidosis (?chronic as baseline bicarb
   seems to be high 30s) as well as a lactic acidosis.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] allow higher PCO2
   - IVFs for lactic acidosis
   .
   # ARF:  Baseline Cr is 0.8.  This is likely due to hypovolemia in the
   setting of poor po intake v. ATN from cardiac arrest.  Also on
   levofloxacin as outpatient.  Had IV contrast for CT torso, so may
   worsen.
   - IVFs

   - hepatitis panel is pending

   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia:  Baseline HCT is 40.
   - T&S
   - remove femoral line and obtain adequate hemostasis
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - antihypertensives previously held
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - d/ced simvastatin
   .
   # Osteoporosis: d/c calcium, vitamin D
   .
   # Communication: Discussed goals of care with family.  Although they
